habitat_description:
In its winter range within the contiguous U.S., Zonotrichia atricapilla is most abundant in riparian shrub and woodlands,  notably thickets of willow, cottonwood, and/or poison oak (Walker, 1917; Davis, 1973; Zeiner et al., 1990; Evens and Stallcup, 1991; Reinsche, 1994; Norment et al., 1998; Carlisle et al., 2004). Some authors have even stated that the species is restricted to such environments (Davis, 1973); however, others have ascribed golden-crowned sparrows to upland sites, specifically to: mosaics of chaparral and open grassland (Grinnell and Miller, 1944); mountain shrublands of Prunus spp. with Ceanothus, serviceberry, currant, etc. (Carlisle et al., 2004); Oregon white oak woodlands (Anderson, 1980); gardens and developed parks (Sumner, 1933; Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Roberts, 1957; Norment et al., 1998); shrubby understories of open-canopy oak woodlands (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Zeiner et al., 1990); and brushpiles in open-canopy oak woodlands (Gorenzel et al., 1995).

Z. atricapilla sometimes ventures into open grasslands or savanna in close proximity to the habitats listed above (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Robertson, 1957; Davis, 1973).

The species has been documented at elevations ranging from sea level (Browning, 1973) to over 2150 m in Nevada (Austin, 1969).
